article_html:
Headteachers are being urged to reject controversial new tests for four and five-year-olds in their first weeks at school, amid concerns they will be both statistically invalid and harmful to children’s wellbeing.

School leaders attending the annual conference of the National Association of Head Teachers in Liverpool made a passionate appeal to government to “stop imposing external, educationally questionable tests on our youngest children”.

They said they were “deeply concerned” about the new baseline assessments, due to be trialled in a small number of schools in September this year and introduced nationally a year later, claiming children born in the summer months would be put at a particular disadvantage.

One primary headteacher who had sat in on a sample assessment on a child, described it as uninspiring and unimaginative, with the teacher and child sitting side by side looking at a computer tablet.

The tablet asks the child: “Can you say the word parrot?” The child responds. Then the computer asks: “Now can you say the word parrot without the P?”

Judy Shaw, a primary school headteacher from Yorkshire, told the conference: “I’m deeply concerned about the intended introduction of standardised baseline tests, which, from September, will be administered to four- and five-year-olds in the first six weeks of school.”

Although the tests were optional, Shaw said headteachers would inevitably come under pressure to adopt them, even though she believes most children at that age would be unable to show their true ability in a new and unfamiliar environment.

The tests would, she said, damage vital new relationships between teachers and children, and undermine the entire learning environment.

Shaw told conference: “They’re harmful to child wellbeing. Children’s ages on entering the English schooling system can vary by as much as 12 months. The summer-born are likely to be particularly disadvantaged.”

The outgoing government says it wants schools to have better means of measuring a child’s progress, rather than testing children just starting at school.

The scores from the new tests will be used to compare a child’s literacy and numeracy levels when they first enter the school with their levels at the end of seven years of primary education, and schools will then be held accountable for their pupils’ progress.

Dominic Loyd, an NAHT member from Boston, Lincolnshire, told conference the tests were optional and if headteachers did not think they were right for their children, they should choose not to introduce them.

“I boycotted Sats in 2010 and I’m still here,” Lloyd said. “I’d be urging colleagues: if it’s optional, why do it? Because in seven years’ time, things will be very different. We’ll be having a different argument and a different government.”

NAHT members voted overwhelming in favour of a motion opposing the new tests, urging government to “give trust and responsibility back to early-years professionals to assess the needs of these children at a crucial time in their education”.
